AQ1524CPT01 (issued 8/13/2020) - applied for an extension on 3/26/2021 and 6/18/2021 - issued 2/11/2022 -- cb 9/22/2021: no permit changes

AS 3/3/2022 - uploaded the extension, which was issued on 2/11/2022 (set to expire on Feb 13, 2022)

AS 10/20/23 - removed from permit description "The Alaska Gasline Development Corporation applied for an extension on June 18, 2021 in order to "secure the remainder of the funding needed for the project," which "has been complicated and delayed by the pandemic, variable natural gas commodity prices, and limited availability of energy company capital funds." The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation agreed with the company, giving them until August 13, 2023 to start building the Alaska LNG Gas Treatment Plant." --

Description: This permit authorized construction of the Alaska LNG Liquefaction Plant. The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation issued an 18-moth extension on January 22, 2024, giving the company until July 7, 2025 to begin construction. However, Alaska Gasline Development Corporation may request an additional 18-month extension prior to July 7, 2025.

Description: Permit authorizing the modification to an existing compressor station to support the Atlantic Bridge Project.
Documents: [{'id': 'ievachpde53dd6ohjbs1v4lim0', 'name': '2018.4.26_Stony Point Compressor Station_Title V Permit.pdf', 'mediaType': 'application/pdf', 'enablePublicUrl': True, 'signedUrlTimeout': 60, 'uploadUrlTimeout': 86400, 'size': 92457, 'version': 1, 'url': 'https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/ol1i53tm8d7f78th11d86vfb9k'}]
Documents_OLD: {'name': None, 'file_name': '2018.4.26_Stony Point Compressor Station_Title V Permit.pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/88/c7/88c79827a080440e9c19544db7fa313e.1644339334.pdf'}
ResearchNotes: 3-3928-00001/00027 (issued 4/26/2018) -- Emissions taken from permit, pg. 7. Owned by Algonquin Gas Transmission, the Stony Point station was included on the list of stations for which EDF received compliance reports through their FOIA.  It’s located about 30 miles north-northwest of New York City and is within a few miles of a lot of densely-populated parts of Rockland County. It’s also right across the Hudson from much of northern Westchester County, and about 12 miles northeast of the border with New Jersey (which is very densely populated in that part). It abuts Harriman and Bear Mountain State Parks,  and is about two miles west of the Hudson. --

ResearchNotes:
PSD-LA-781 (issued 5/23/2014, extended on 7/23/2015 and 2/6/2017) -- To construct the G2G Plant, a facility that would produce methanol from natural gas and then convert methanol to gasoline.

First extension: app submitted 6/9/2015, issued 7/23/2015, extended to 5/23/2017
Second extension: app submitted 1/25/2017, issued 3/15/2017, extended to 11/23/2018. Permit mod issued in 2019 extended construction date to 10/25/2020 and changed plant design to only include methanol portion of the process.

"The name plate production capacity for the G2G Plant will be approximately 12,500 petroleum barrels per day (bbl/day) of gasoline on an annual average
basis. To achieve this gasoline production, the facility will produce approximately 3,800 metric tons per day (mtpd) of methanol on an annual average basis. The process is expected to produce various by-products, including liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), fuel gas, purge gas, and waste water, which will be utilized in the plant to the maximum extent feasible or commercially viable." --

ResearchNotes: R13-3216A (5/24/2016) -- Construction commenced 11/10/2016; startup on 2/8/2017. Emissions seen here are facility-wide post-mod totals taken from R13-3216E Fact Sheet, page 5. R13-3216A modified the engine catalyst efficiencies based on new catalyst information, addition of two (2) new compressor engines, increase the glycol dehydrator throughputs, and remove the fuel limit on the compressor engines. The removal of the fuel limit results in the facility no longer being a synthetic minor. R13-3216B updated storage tank and loading emissions, new fuel conditioning heater, increases glycol dehydration throughput, updates fugitive counts and modifies blowdown and pigging events. R13-3216C authorized one (1) Capstone 200 kWe microturbine generator and removal of permit condition 5.1.3. limiting use to one unit at a time. R13-3216D was a Class I Admin Update to SIC codes. R13-3216E removed one Capstone generator (200 kW) and added one 684 hp PSI 21.9L Certified industrial generator. --

ResearchNotes:
R13-3201 (issued 12/29/2014), R13-3201A (issued 11/20/2015),  R13-3201A (issued 4/26/2016) -- R13-3201A authorizes a catalytic heater and updates emissions calculations and fuel usage limitation; constitutes a synthetic minor for NOx and CO.

R13-3201B modifies the engine catalyst efficiencies based on new catalyst information, addition of two (2) new compressor engines, increase the glycol dehydrator throughputs, and remove the fuel limit on the compressor engines. The removal of the fuel limit results in the facility no longer being a synthetic minor.

R13-3201C increases the glycol dehydrator throughput, adds a fuel conditioning heater, increases the size of the settling tank, modifies the compressor blowdown and pigging events based on expected operations, and updates the fugitive component counts. --

Description: This significant permit modification authorized construction of the Big Lake Fuels Methanol Plant and modified the plant's original design to only include the natural gas to methanol portion of the process. On September 18, 2020, Big Lake Fuels LLC requested a third extension, citing delays in obtaining its water quality certification from the Army Corps of Engineers. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality issued the extension on October 20th, giving the company until April 25, 2022, to begin construction. Another extension was issued on April 11, 2023, pushing back the deadline to start building the plant to October 25, 2023. On February 19, 2024, Big Lake Fuels asked to rescind the permits associated with the proposed facility. If the company wants to develop the site, it will have to reapply for new permits.

ResearchNotes: R13-3285A (issued 11/14/2016), R13-3285B (issued 3/28/2017), R13-3285C (issued 1/2/2020), R13-3285 (issued 5/25/2016) -- Emissions are facility-wide post-mod totals taken from R13-3285B permit application, page 113, non-fugitive + fugitive PTE. Construction commenced on 11/30/2016. R13-3285A authorized Modification primarily to: (1) Replace the thirteen (13) permitted Waukesha 7044 GSI compressor engines with eight (8) Caterpillar 03608 engines, (2) Installation of a new fuel conditioning heater, (3) Increase the Glycol Dehydrator Units throughput each to 110 mmscf/day, and (4) Revision of the dehydrator flash tank control efficiency (VOCs and HAPs increased; decreases in all other criteria pollutants; GHGs increased 713.69). R13-3285B is a Class 2 Admin Update that authorized: (1) The pigging events were increased from 52 and separated into 198 low pressure pigging venting and 260 high pressure pigging venting events per year; (2) Increase the number of compressor blowdown/startups from 132 to 936 events per year. These changes will result in an increase of a Potential to Emit (PTE) of 9.63 TPY of VOCs, 0.25 TPY of HAPs, and 915 TPY of carbon dioxide equivalents. R13-3285C is a Class 1 admin update that authorized changes SIC code from 4923 to 1311; no emissions increases. --

R13-3281A authorized updates to compressor engine emissions based on new catalyst design, installation of two additional compressor engines, eliminating the fuel use limit on the compressors, increasing dehy throughput to 88 mmscfd each, and modifying flash tank control efficiency (GHGs increased by 27k). R13-3281B authorized One (1) 0.5 MMBtu/hr fuel conditioning heater is being added to the inlet fuel gas line to allow more complete combustion at the compressor engines (GHGs increased 300 tpy). R13-3281C is an administrative update to update NAICS/SIC codes and determine status of adjacent facilities. --

ResearchNotes: R13-3166A (issued 5/4/2015), R13-3166B (withdrawn 9/9/2015), R13-3166C (issued 5/15/2017), R13-3166D (issued 10/30/2017), R13-3166E (issued 10/24/2019), R13-3166F (issued 12/1/2020), R13-3166 (issued 8/22/2014) -- Emissions are facility-wide totals taken from permit application for R13-3166F, page 74. R13-3166A updated operating conditions of NSCR catalysts, tank production numbers, and removal of VRU from truck loading. R13-3166B was withdrawn; Class 2 admin update to modify permitting language re hours of operation for microturbines. R13-3166C authorized the addition of two (2) engines, updated operating conditions of NSC catalysts, increase of glycol dehydration throughput, addition of fuel conditioning heater, emission updates and elimination of synthetic minor status. R13-3166D replaced one (1) 1,680 hp Waukesha compressor engine with one (1) 1,900 hp Waukesha L 7044GSI compressor engine. R13-3166E was a Class 1 administrative update; no change in emissions. R13-3166F (application pending as of 10/26/2020) is a Class 2 administrative update that would update venting emissions and change SIC code to 4922. --

ResearchNotes: Emissions seen here are facility-wide post-mod totals taken from R13-2913C Fact Sheet, page 5. TV permit issued 1/29/2019. R13-2913A was an "after the fact" modification to reduce control efficiencies, update PTE for compressor engines, revise emissions from the glycol dehydration units (CO and VOCs increased, -0.28 reduction in HAPs). R13-2913B authorized "modifications to account for facility build-out" and updated assumptions/parmeters for emissions estimations (GHGs +20,664). R13-2913C authorized installation of a compressor engine, emergency generator, and other small facility build-outs (GHGs +24,455).

ResearchNotes: R13-3491 (issued 8/3/2020 and willReplace G35-D127), G35-D127 (issued 9/22/2017) -- Emissions fro R13-3491 (issued 8/3/2020), which replaced General Permit Registration (G35-D127B). R13-3491 authorized: 1) Increase the rated horsepower of each CAT G3616 A4 engine from 5,000 bhp to 5,350 bhp; 2). Update emission estimates using a “richer” (i.e., higher VOC/HAP content) gas analysis; 3) Change thermal oxidizer VOC/HAP control efficiency to reflect the vendor guaranteed control efficiency of 99.5%. Led to emissions reductions for all pollutants except PM and HAPs --

Description: EPA Region 6 permit authorizing construction of the offshore Deepwater Port component of the Bluewater SPM project. On September 1, 2022, in response to public comments submitted by the Environmental Integrity Project and a coalition of 15 allied organizations, the EPA Region Six Office in Dallas wrote to Bluewater Texas Terminals LLC asking the company to withdraw its proposed permit and submit a new proposal that would incorporate pollution controls for smog-forming volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs). The pollution controls would reduce Bluewater’s emissions of toxic air pollution by at least 95 percent. Bluewater withdrew the PSD application on 10/3/2022.

Description: Permit authorizing construction of Brightmark's Dayton Yard Facility. Brightmark applied to extend the deadline to begin constructing the new plant on January 10, 2023, nearly three months after the permit expired. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality granted the extension on January 27th, giving the company until April 13, 2024 to start building the Dayton Yard Facility.

ResearchNotes:
With this modification, CF's Donaldsonville Nitrogen Complex is proposing an expansion consisting of
the addition of the following process units to the existing facility.
• No. 6 Ammonia Plant- 1,460,000 tons per year (tpy)
• No. 5 Urea Plant- 1,405,250 tpy
• No. 4 Nitric Acid Plant - 657,000 tpy
• No. 3 Urea Ammonium Nitrate (UAN) Plant - 1, 788,500 tpy

ResearchNotes: R13-3207B (issued 10/1/2018), R13-3207C (issued 8/6/2019), R13-3207A (issued 12/30/2015), R13-3207D (issued 6/26/2020) -- Emissions taken from R13-3207D, Fact Sheet, page 3 (total facility wide post mod PTE). Construction began in 2016, prior to permit issuance. Notice of violation was served 9/15/2015. R13-3207A authorizes increase to the current liquid loading throughputs and increase the existing dehydration unit capacity (from 150 to 200 million standard cubic feet per day), as well as install one (1) additional dehydration unit with associated reboiler and ground flare, one (1) compressor engine, one (1) microtuibine generator, one (1) Hot Oil Heater associated with a condensate stabilizer, three (3) storage tanks, one (1) blowdown flare and one (1) backup vapor destruction unit [VDU]. Rl3-3207B revises the hourly and annual emission limits for the five compressor engines; update emissions from the dehydration units to account for the maximum glycol pump rates; update the miscellaneous storage tank list; VRU compressors have been replaced with smaller electric motor driven units; revise the condensate and produce water permitted throughputs; and emissions when the pig chambers (launchers/receivers) are depressurized to atmosphere pressure. R13-3207C authorizes Installation of two (2) engines, update emission and volumetric limits and include an emergency generator. R13-3207D Updates condensate liquid loading operations from atmospheric truck loading to atmospheric or pressurized truck loading. Additionally, operate the liquid loading vapor destruction unit on a full-time basis and increase blowdown volumes sent to the blowdown emergency flare. --

Description: Permit modification to add five natural gas-fired compressor engines, three 400 bbl produced water/condensate tanks and a process flare at Willow Lake 1, and to revise the capacity of two existing reboilers and increase the capacity of one triethylene glycol (TEG) dehydrator unit.

ResearchNotes:
5142-M7 superseded GCP‐4‐5142‐M6 (and is the facility's initial minor NSR, although the plant was authorized in 2013):

GCP-4-5142 (issued 8/27/2013) to construct the 30 MMscf/d Willow Plant

5142-M1 (issued 9/12/2014) authorized removal of the CAT 3508B LE, addition of the CAT G399 generator, regeneration heater increase to 2 MMbtu, one large NGL tank in place of three smaller tanks, and a change in the condensate loading rate to 300 bbls/week.

5142-M2 (issued 11/2/2015) authorized > Updating the glycol dehydrator dry gas flow rate to 30 MMscf/day on units D1 and D2 > Update the naming on unit Reboil-D1 to HTR DEHY > Update the naming on unit Htr-1 to MS Heater > Remove reboil units Reboil-DD and Reboil-D2 > Replace PIG (SSM) with unit SSM/M to account for startup, shutdown, maintenance, and malfunction

5142-M3 (withdrawn) > The applicant withdrew this permit application because the facility received commercial power supply before the permit was issued and no longer needed the generator that was going to be installed with this permitting action.

5142-M4 (issued 2/2/2016) authorized >Adding three pressurized NGL storage tanks; > Adding one Joule-Thomson (J-T) skid; > Removing Caterpillar G399; > Adding two Waukesha VHP L7044 engines; > Adding a flare (unit FL-1); > Adding a hot oil heater (unit H-HTR); > Adding a 210-bbl slop tank (unit S-TK); > Removing amine system (units Amine-1 and HTR-AMINE).

5142-M6 (issued 2/7/2018) authorized Adding one 50 MMscf/day triethylene glycol (TEG) dehydrator downstream of the cryogenic separation unit at Willow Lake 1; > Adding one 1.5 MMBTU/hr heater for the TEG dehydration unit; > Updating facility‐wide fugitive emissions to better represent emissions at the facility; > Updating control efficiency of the dehydration units D1 and D2 to better reflect the actual expected destruction efficiency of emissions from these units; > Adding one 210 bbl produced water/condensate tank at Willow Lake 2; and > Updating the Crestwood New Mexico Pipeline LLC company address.

Description: This permit authorizes construction of the Cronus Ammonia Plant, which was originally authorized on September 5, 2014 under Permit No. 1306007. Cronus Chemicals submitted the application in November 2019, but the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency deemed it incomplete in February 2020. In November 2023, the application was deemed complete and a draft permit was issued. This permit supersedes the initial pre-construction permit issued in 2014.

ResearchNotes:
Permit no. 1306007 was issued 9/5/2014; revised on 12/17/2015, granting an additional 18 months extension to commence construction by 10/8/2017. "The principal product of the facility would be urea and the facility would have a nominal daily urea production capacity of 4880 tons. Ammonia would be an intermediate material used in the production of urea."

Application no. 19110020 (initially submitted 11/27/2019) supersedes 2014 permit - still administratively incomplete and not available online, obtained through FOIA on 5/11/2021. Confirmed that the permit is still pending via FOIA/phone conversation with permit engineer (AS, 8/17/2021).

New facility design increases ammonia capacity by 450 mtpd (but halves total production - from 4880 tons/day urea to 2750 tons/day ammonia)

FOIA'd draft and/or final permit in Jan 2022, recieved response January 25, 2022 - no drafts or final permits. Docs produced included preliminary draft permit sections, but a draft permit has not been completed yet. (GB 2/9/2022)

ResearchNotes:
MarkWest Utica EMG, L.L.C. (MarkWest) plans to construct a greenfield natural gas processing plant in Noble County south of Senecaville Lake (Seneca Gas Processing Plant) to process field gas mainly gathered from the Utica shale formation. Plants #1 and #2 at the Seneca Gas Processing Plant will each process up to 230 million standard cubic feet per day (mmscfd) of field gas to produce pipeline grade natural gas and a mixture of heavier hydrocarbons (i.e., natural gas liquids [NGLs]) intended for delivery via pipeline to off-site fractionation facilities.

Plants #1 and #2

Description: This permit authorized construction of Polyethylene Plant No. 7 at Dow's Freeport Chemical Plant. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality extended the construction deadline on June 3, 2021, giving the company until September 3, 2022 to start building the new unit. On April 1, 2022, Dow applied for a retroactive permit amendment to add hydrogen as a fuel source for the furnace, and to update emissions calculation and higher heating value (HHV). The permit amendment was issued on January 11, 2023, extending the deadline to begin construction until July 11, 2024.

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the Energy Security Partners GTL Plant. The Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality issued a first 18-month extension on June 9, 2021, giving the company until January 10, 2023 to build the plant, and a second 18-month extension on December 6, 2022, which moved the construction start deadline to July 10, 2024. A renewal application was submitted in July 2024.

ResearchNotes:
1280-00163-V1 (issued 4/25/2014) was a minor mod. to add two cooling towers, add one caustic cooling tower, add a fresh caustic tank. Mod led to increased emissions of PM10/2.5 and SO2, minor (-45 CO2e) decrease in GHGs.

1280-00163-V2 (issued 11/10/2014) was a minor mod. to route the amine regen flash gas and caustic treater off gas to the process flare; move 2 existing diesel fired engines from insignificant activities; add one diesel emergency generator; incorporate 2 case by case insignificant activities.

EPA Permit GHGPSDTX33:
Voluntary updates issued 11/15/2019
-- 11/19/2020 to incorporate modifications in New Source Review (NSR) Permit No.
107523 dated July 15, 2020 to include updated flare (emission point number [EPN] SK25.801) operating scenarios and fugitive (EPNs FUG-PDH and FUG-NGAS) counts. The amendment to Permit No. 107523 (Project No. 301341) did not
trigger PSD review for non-GHG pollutants. The current application also requests corrections of the regeneration air compressor gas turbines’ (Facility Identification Number [FIN] GT26.101A and GT26.101B) emission calculations and stack representations. (increase in GHGs = +10,508)**
-- 3/24/2021 to make minor updates to permit conditions, which would not result in changes to GHG emissions

R13-3269B was a major mod to update emissions associated w/ blowdowns, pig receivers, glycol dehydration, storage tanks (VOCs increased by ~42 tpy, GHGs by ~1000). GHG emission totals taken from permit application for R13-3269B, submitted 8/7/2017, page 108, total facility post-mod pte. --

Description: This permit, which was originally issued to Equinor Pipelines LLC, authorized construction of the Trenton Central RVP Station. Grayson Mill Operating LLC acquired Equinor's upstream and midstream assets in North Dakota in early 2021. The North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality issued an 18-month extension on October 28, 2021, giving the company until May 4, 2023 to begin construction on the facility.

GP5-63-01001 and GP1-63-01001 (issued 8/3/2016),  GP1-63-01001A and AG5-63-00004A (issued 8/7/2018) -- 1/3/2022 PA DEP Memo
"Under the August 7, 2018 GP-5 Authorization, ETC was authorized to operate the existing cryogenic process unit at Rev Cryo Plant (Rev Cryo Unit 1), and authorized to construct a second cryogenic process unit at Rev Cryo Plant (Rev Cryo Unit 2). Under the August 7, 2018 GP5 Authorization and Department regulation (25 Pa. Code § 127.13(b)), construction of Rev Cryo Unit 2 must have commenced within 18 months of the GP5 authorization, or February 7, 2020, unless extended by the Department. On February 6, 2020, the Department granted ETC’s request for an eighteen-month extension of the period in which ETC must commence construction of Rev Cryo Unit 2 to August 7, 2021. No further extensions have been approved."

Description: These general permits authorized construction of the Revolution Cryogenic Gas Processing Plant. (A GP-5 is a state-issued general permit that covers air emissions from natural gas compression stations, processing plants, and transmission stations. A GP-1 is a  state-issued general permit that covers air emissions from small gas- and oil-fired combustion units.)

Description: Permit modified to incorporate a new catalyst into the polypropylene production process, which would include a new refrigeration unit with a vacuum system and a back-up generator.

ResearchNotes: 0840-00003-V7 (issued 3/21/2018); 0840-00003-V8 (issued 3/8/2019); 0840-00003-V9 (Issued 11/14/2019) -- "With this modification, ExxonMobil requested a project for a new additive/catalyst to be used in the Polypropylene Plant. This catalyst will produce a new grade of polypropylene. No increase in polypropylene production will be realized, as the new grade will replace existing production for approximately 650 hours annually using the existing processing equipment. The new catalyst will require refrigeration. Therefore, a new enclosure will be constructed to house the catalyst at cooler temperatures. The project will have a vacuum system with a bag filter for particulate emission controls. Also added is a back-up generator on the enclosure to keep the refrigeration system operating in the event of a power failure." --

ResearchNotes: AQ1201CPT01 (issued 8/20/2012), AQ1201CPT02 (issued 6/12/2013), AQ1201CPT03 (issued 8/7/2014, revised 1/23/2015), AQ1201MSS03 (issued 2/27/2015, revised 3/27/2015, 3/4/2016, 6/20/2016, 8/26/2016, 4/17/2017), AQ1201MSS04 (issued 6/24/2019) -- Project was initially authorized under AQ1201CPT01 (issued 8/20/2012). Changes to project scope/engineering design = AQ1201CPT02 (issued 6/12/2013), AQ1201CPT03 (issued 8/7/2014, revised 1/23/2015). **Minor permit mod. (AQ1201MSS03) to limit certain emissions treated as *another* change in project scope. Permit (issued 2/27/2015) states that "the Department is treating ExxonMobil’s minor permit application as another change to the project scope. While ExxonMobil has previously reported that actual construction, as defined in 40 CFR 52.21(b)(11), began on March 5, 2013, the production facility is still under construction. The application therefore regards the construction and operation of a new stationary source, rather than the modification an existing stationary source." Minor permit mod (AQ1201MSS04, issued 6/25/2019) supersedes Minor Permit AQ1201MSS03 Revision 5. Authorizes addition of 3 new heaters (EUs 152, 162, and 163), and the addition of 16 new nonroad engines, EUs 150, 151, 153 through 161, and 164 through 168. Revisions to previous limits, deletion of previous conditions that have been satisfied, and the addition of a new ORL to avoid PSD for CO. --

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the FG LA Complex. On September 14, 2022, Louisiana’s 19th Judicial District Court reversed the LDEQ’s decision to issue air permits that Formosa Plastics needed to build its proposed petrochemical complex in St. James Parish, including this air construction permit and operating permits. The State Agency appealed the decision on October 3rd and issued a second 18-month extension on December 5th, giving the company until July 6, 2024 to start construction. On January 19, 2024, a Louisiana appellate court reinstated the permit. On March 22, 2024, the state agency approved a third request to extend the deadline to start construction, giving Formosa until January 6, 2026. However, it must submit a Title V permit renewal application that demonstrates that emissions from the plant will not cause or contribute to a violation of the recently revised PM 2.5 National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) by July 6, 2024.

ResearchNotes:
PSD-LA-812 issued 1/6/2021, construction extension issued on 7/6/2021. Louisiana court vacated the permit and remanded it, along with 14 TV permits for the plant, back to LDEQ on September 14, 2022.

LDEQ filed a suspensive appeal on 10/3/2022. A suspensive appeal suspends execution of the judgement pending outcome of the appeal and requires posting of a security bond with the Clerk of City Court in an amount of one and one-half times the judgment rendered. pending before the 1st circuit court of appeals as of 1/3/22 - LA's state appellate court, not the federal first circuit, which covers ME, MA, NH, etc. so it's an appeal from the state trial court (lowest court) to the state appellate court (middle court)
https://edms.deq.louisiana.gov/app/doc/view?doc=13499791
https://www.brla.gov/DocumentCenter/View/185/Appeals-Fact-Sheet-PDF -- AS 1/3/22 - removed from permit description: The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality (LDEQ) issued an 18-month extension, giving the company until January 6, 2023 to start construction. --

CP15-077 (issued 8/16/2016). Facility obtained variances to begin construction before the permit was issued: "On December 23, 2015, the Nebraska Department of Environmental Quality (NDEQ) received application #15-077 from Fortigen to construct the anhydrous ammonia production facility. On January 5, 2016, the NDEQ received a variance request from Fortigen to construct the facility prior to receiving a construction permit (CP) from the NDEQ. On March 29, 2016, the NDEQ issued a variance to Fortigen to construct their facility, with additional stipulations. On April 6, 2016, the NDEQ issued an updated variance to Fortigen to construct additional equipment not covered in the first variance." - from permit fact sheet, p. 1

Emissions seen here are site-wide post-mod totals from G35-D135B Fact Sheet (pg. 4). Expansion authorized under B not yet installed at time of inspection (12/4/2019). Compliance report (submitted 9/18/2020) for the period 6/22/2019-6/21/2020 shows only 6 (out of 11) compressor engines operating. Unclear if modifications permitted under B are operating as of 4/7/2021. Nothing on project timeline in permit application. --

Description: Permits authorizing initial construction of the Golden Pass LNG Export Terminal. Description: This permit authorized construction of the Gulf Access Bulk Liquids Storage Terminal, and was extended on November 29, 2018. PTC14089 (issued 12/11/2014 amended 2/12/2020)

Initial TV issued 9/22/2020 -- Hess Hawkeye Gas Facility received Permit to Construct No. PTC14089 in December of 2014 and completed construction on February 6,2017. PTC14089 allowed Hess to build a new compressor station directly south of the currently decommissioned Hawkeye Compressor Station. On June 14,2019, the Department received a permit to construct application from Hess with a request to amend the existing Permit to Construct No. PTC14089. The application represented updated emissions calculations due to a change in existing emission unit hourly usage, an updated carbon monoxide AP-42 factor, and additional flaring at the facility --

Description: Permit authorizing restart of the Westlake Ethylene Plant and modifications to expand production capacity. Description: This permit modifies Permit Nos. 0520-00107-V2 and PSD-LA-813 (M-2), which were issued on November 15, 2018 and authorized emissions from the Westlake Ethylene Plant. This significant permit modification reconciles emissions rates and incorporates a number of "as-built" design changes that were made during construction of the facility, including the installation of pollution control devices on three boilers.

Description: This permit authorized construction of the cracking furnace expansion. It was withdrawn in 2015 following the Supreme Court ruling in UARG v. EPA S. Ct. 2427, which held that EPA may not use greenhouse gas emissions alone to determine whether a source is required to obtain a PSD or Title V permit.

Description: To authorize the ADN Upgrade Project, which would improve the distributed control system and implementation of advanced process controls for the adiponitrile (ADN) unit, including: upgrades to the natural gas plant, Installation of a new natural gas catalytic cracker, and reliability, availability, and efficiency improvements, including equipment replacement.

Description: Permits authorizing construction of the Heavy Condensate Upgrader Project. During a public hearing held in Brownsville on May 28, 2019, hundreds of individuals, community groups, and government entities requested a contested case hearing on the company's draft Clean Air Act pre-construction permit, issued May 16, 2019. The contested case hearing was held on February 8, 2021 and the attached decision was issued on May 21, 2021. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) issued the final permits on October 19. On September 9, 2022, the construction deadline for the project was extended from April 19, 2023 to October 19, 2024. On October 4, 2024, the deadline to begin construction was extended for a second time, until April 19, 2026, because TCEQ determined that the company "met the financial commitment required" to warrant a second extension.

During the comment period, the Shrimpers and Fishermen of the Rio Grande Valley submitted timely comments (as did several hundred other individuals, community groups, and government entities), and requested a contested case hearing on the Draft Permit. The hearing was held on February 8, 2021 and a decision was issued on May 21, 2021.

Applied for extension for construction until May 1, 2021 on 10/30/2019 (permit application for major modification). Issued new PSD under new AI number, arguing the initial PSD was technically issued to the wrong company. Construction expected to commence in 2021. Energy Transfer said it expected to make a final investment decision by early 2021 on whether to build the plant, a delay from its earlier timeline for a decision by late 2020.

Can't tell if this is the same project, https://seekingalpha.com/news/3796204-energy-transfer-requests-extension-to-2028-for-lake-charles-lng-project (GB 2/24/2022)

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the Lake Charles Methanol Facility, which was modified on June 30, 2016 to incorporate minor design changes related to the facility's boilers and heaters. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality has already granted three extensions to construct the Lake Charles Methanol Facility: on August 1, 2017; June 29, 2018; and February 22, 2019. The last extension expired on August 24, 2020.

ResearchNotes:
PSD-LA-803 (issued 2/24/2016), PSD-LA-803 (M1) (issued 6/30/2016, extended on 8/1/2017 and 8/29/2018; expired 8/24/2020); Title V Air Permit No. 0520-00492-V2 (application submitted 8/21/2020) -- Applied for extension for construction until August 24, 2020 on 2/22/2019, citing financing delays. The project is targeting financial closing and construction start mid-2021. Applied to renew TV permit on 8/21/2020. Permit was administratively continued and is still pending issuance. Site was inspected on 4/23/2021 and it was determined that construction has not commenced.

PSD-LA-803 & 0520-00492-V0 (issued 2/24/2016)

PSD-LA-803 (M1) & 0520-00492-V1 (issued 6/30/2016, deadline to construct = 8/24/2017) --> minor mod to make miscl. design updates and authorizes operational flexibility w/ boilers (minor emissions decreases)

1. : application to extend M1/V1 permits submitted 7/21/2017; First 12-month extension issued 8/1/2017, extending construction deadline to 8/24/2018

1 1/2: application to extend submitted 5/30/2018; 6-month extension issued 6/29/2018, new deadline = 2/24/2019

2. application to extend submitted 11/26/2018 and 2/3/2018, 18-month extension issued 2/22/2019, new deadline = 8/24/2020

Title V Air Permit No. 0520-00492-V2 (application submitted 8/21/2020) --

These sources were built as part of the Lake Charles Chemicals Project and originally permitted on May 23, 2014 under Permit No. PSD-LA-779, including: the Low Density Polyethylene Unit, Linear Low Density Polyethylene Unit, Ethylene 2 Unit, Steam 2 Unit, Wastewater Treatment Plant 2, and Utilities, Offsites, and Infrastructure.

ResearchNotes:
LyondellBasell and Sasol have entered into an agreement to form a 50/50 joint venture (JV) company through which Lyondell Basell will acquire 50 percent of Sasol's Lake Charles Chemical Complex (LCCC) 1.5 million ton ethane cracker, 0.9 million ton low and linear low-density polyethylene plants and all associated infrastructure.

Sasol permitted these units through an expansion to the LCCC initially authorized on May 23, 2014 under Permit No. PSD-LA-779. The join venture is proposing to incorporate the following units and their corresponding emission sources to a new stand-alone PSD permit: Ethylene 2 (ETH2), Low Density Polyethylene (LDPE), LinearLow Density Polyethylene (LLDPE), Steam 2 (STM2), Wastewater Treatment Plant 2 (WWTP2), and Utilities, Offsites, and Infrastructure (UO&I).

Description: Initial Title V and PSD permit for the construction and operation of the Eunice Compressor Station located in Acadia Parish, Louisiana. As a result of the June 23, 2014 ruling by the U.S Supreme Court on the greenhouse Gas Tailoring Rule, PSD review no longer applies to the Eunice Compressor Station, and the PSD application was subsequently withdrawn on December 10, 2014.

ResearchNotes:
R13-2818G (issued 3/21/2017), R13-2818H (issued 11/28/2017), R13-2818I (issued 4/3/2020), R13-2818J (issued 7/20/2020) -- R13-2818G authorized initial construction of Plant 7.

R13-2818H (issued 11/28/2017) updated emissions calculations following an audit that showed combusted volument at the flare (FL-991, FL-1991) should be updated. This is due to increased volumes being sent to the flare that were not accounted for in the previous permit (R13-2818G).

R13-2818I was issued 4/3/2020 for a Class II administrative replace three (3) emergency generators with different models and change permit limit for Flare FL-1991 and incorporate USEPA Consent Decree requirements.

R13-2818J (issued 7/20/2020) was a Class I administrative amendment to clarify permitting conditions, and did not result in emissions increases. --

Description: This permit would authorize the construction of eight new storage tanks, seven marine loading docks (and associated vapor combustion units), three firewater pumps, and piping fugitives at Max Midstream's Seahawk Terminal. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) issued the final permit on April 8, 2022, denying local shrimpers’ request for a permit hearing. However, on November 30, 2023, a Travis County District Court reversed TCEQ's decision and remanded the Order back to the Commission for a contested case hearing.

ResearchNotes:
Geismar Methanol Plants 1 and 2: PSD-LA-761 (issued 11/7/2012), PSD-LA-761 (M1) (issued 9/12/2013), PSD-LA-761 (M2) (issued 1/14/2014), PSD-LA-761 (M3) (issued 12/22/2016), PSD-LA-761 (M4) (issued 12/22/2016)

PSD-LA-761 (M-5) (issued 4/8/2019), PSD-LA-761 (M-6) (issued 11/6/2019) -- PSD-LA-761 (M-6) (issued 11/6/2019) reconciles emissions estimates and BACT limitations. Minor CO and VOC increases added to project total (M6 final permit, pg. 7). Permit expiration date = M6 issuance date + 18 months. FID on plant 3 made in July 2019 -- Methanex announced that they're reevaluating capital and operating spending for Geismar Plant 3 on March 16, 2020. Project delayed. Construction expected to begin 7/2022. --

ResearchNotes: 2017-0879-C (issued 8/14/2017),  2017-0879-C (M-1) (issued 11/29/2018) -- HAP = Formaldehyde. Criteria emissions taken from M1 final permit, page 4. GHGs and all other criteria from M1 app, page 14. Initial permit authorized two (2) 1,875-hp Caterpillar G3606LE compressor engines with oxidation catalysts, one (1) 210-bbl condensate storage tank, one (1) 210-bbl wastewater storage tank, one (1) 500-gal wastewater sump, condensate truck loading, fugitive emissions, and vents and blowdowns, and other support operations. After M-1 mod: After these changes, the facility will consist of two (2) 1,380-hp Caterpillar G3516J natural gasfired engines, one (1) 100-bbl condensate storage tank, one ( 1) 100-bbl wastewater storage tank, one (1) 500-gal wastewater sump, condensate truck loading, wastewater truck loading, fugitive emissions, vents and blowdowiis, and other support operations. All emissions but NOx descreased after M1 mod. --

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the Midwest Fertilizer Plant in Posey County. The Indiana Department of Environmental Management granted an extension on September 28, 2015, giving the company until June 4, 2017 to start building the new facility.

ResearchNotes:
First extension to commence construction submitted 9/14/2015; issued 9/28/2015** extending deadline to construct to 6/4/2017.
**"response to review request" issued 9/25/2015, which is the agency review doc, from my understanding, based on the language used in the permit app re permitting history (see below) (AS 1/8/2021)

Second extension to commence construction submitted 3/14/2017 and 3/23/2017; issued 5/9/2017, extending deadline to construct to 9/23/2018.

Third extension to commence construction submitted 3/2/2020; issued 3/17/2020, extending deadline to construct to 9/23/2021. -- "Midwest Fertilizer Company, LLC (Midwest Fertilizer) was issued a major Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) New Source Construction and Part 70 Operating Permit on June 4, 2014 (T-129-33576-00059) for a stationary nitrogen fertilizer manufacturing facility to be located in Mt. Vernon, Posey County, Indiana. Subsequently, an extension to the time for “commencing” construction was granted on September 28, 2015 (T-129-36272-00059)." --

Description: Permit No. 129-40421-00059 was a significant modification that revised the Best Available Control Technology (BACT) assessment for the Midwest Fertilizer plant's reformer furnace. The Indiana Department of Environmental Management granted a fourth extension on March 17, 2020 (Permit No. 129-42647-00059), giving the company until September 23, 2021 to begin construction.

These two actions included an updated full air quality assessment and a revised BACT assessment for the reformer furnace (EU-001). An additional 18-month extension was granted on March 17, 2020 (129-42647-00059) with a new date set at September 23, 2021.

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the Bradford County LNG Facility. The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection granted two permit extensions—on September 15, 2020 and July 22, 2021—giving the company until July 22, 2022 to begin construction. Per a settlement entered into on March 18, 2022, Bradford County LNG's construction permit was allowed to expire on July 22, 2022. If the project were to proceed, the company would have to apply for a new air construction permit.

Description: Permit authorizing the initial construction of the Kalama Methanol Manufacturing and Marine Export Facility. An extension to the deadline to construct from December 7, 2018 to March 4, 2021, was issued in September 2019. On June 11, 2021, Northwest Innovation Works announced the cancellation of the construction of the facility authorized by this permit, as the facility was unable to secure the necessary additional state permits to proceed with the project.

ResearchNotes:
GHGPSDTX155 (issued 1/5/2017), PSDTX1326 (issued 1/10/2014), 19778 (amended 1/10/2014 and 10/06/2014) -- https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=iwr.pgmdetail&addn_id=786367732016042&re_id=430060532002089&program_code=AIRNSR&lgcy_sys_cd=NSR&program=AIR%20NEW%20SOURCE%20PERMITS&IdType=EPA%20PERMIT

"At the time of approval of the amendments of 1/10/2014 and 10/06/2014, Agrium anticipated producing as by-product large amounts of Carbon dioxide (CO2) and selling sufficient CO2 so that greenhouse gas (GHG) Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) applicability review would not be required. Since then, market demand for CO2 has fallen and Agrium anticipates releasing to the atmosphere the CO2 which cannot be sold. The project authorized in 2014 was subject to PSD Review for criteria pollutant emission rate increases (authorized by Permit Nos. 19778 and PSDTX1326). Therefore, GHG PSD applicability review is now required." --

Description: Permit authorizing the restart of one ammonia and one urea plant (Plants 4 and 5) at the Kenai Nitrogen Operations facility. This permit incorporates minor design changes and supersedes the initial construction permit, AQ0083CPT06, which was originally issued on January 5, 2015, and extended twice: first on March 4, 2016, and again on October 3, 2017. The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation has already granted two additional extensions, first on July 22, 2022 and then again on February 9, 2024. Nutrien has until September 26, 2025 to start building the new units.

"if construction has not commenced by the new deadline set forth in this
letter, the Department will require a new PSD construction permit application be submitted concurrently with a 3rd PSD extension request in order for the 3rd PSD extension request to be considered." -2nd PSD extension approval, dated 2/9/24

Incorporates minor design changes, including replacement of the existing Solar Turbines rated at 37.6 MMBtu/hr with new Solar Turbines that would be rated at 55.443 MMBtu/hr, and installation of Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) for NOx control on the Package Boilers (Units 44, 48, and 49). The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation (ADEC) extended the deadline by which construction must commence twice: first on March 4, 2016, extending the deadline until January 6, 2018, and again on October 3, 2017, extending the deadline by another 18-months, until July 6, 2019.https://dec.alaska.gov/air/air-permit/nutrien-kenai-nitrogen-operation

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of Fractionation Trains 1 and 2 at the Permico Robstown Fractionator. On June 25, 2020, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) issued an extension until February 5, 2022 to begin constructing the facility. On November 15, 2021, Permico applied for a second extension, citing delays from "litigation with a shareholder that pushed the company into Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection." The TCEQ granted the second extension on November 22, 2021, giving the company until August 5, 2023 to begin construction on the Robstown Fractionator. On August 14, 2023, in response to an inquiry made by EIP regarding the permit's validity, the TCEQ voided the permit.

Description: Construction of a new 250 million cubic feet per day (MMcf/d) gas processing plant. The Sanderson Gas Plant would be connected to a new 80-mile gathering system capable of transporting more than 450 MMcf/d of natural gas from southeastern Williams County. The new facility would be connected to two pipeline systems in the northwest corner of the Bakken, including the Northern Border Pipeline and the Oneok NGL Pipeline.
ResearchNotes: PTC20021 (issued 4/24/2020) -- Construction began in May 2020 and took 8 months to complete. The project is anchored by a long-term gas gathering and processing agreement with XTO Energy Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of ExxonMobil (OGJ Online, Jan. 7, 2020). --

Permit application (9/6/2018) states that BLNG previously held air permit no. 07793R04, which was rescinded 8/22/2013. FOIA submitted 10/20/2020 for permit applications and technical docs. for R01 and R02 permits. R01 modification authorizes minor revisions to the permit to clarify equipment descriptions, modify the approach to ensure ongoing compliance with the synthetic minor limit, and to propose changes to the scope of the annual inspections required for the flare. R02 modification was an administrative amendment to correct the emission limit values and units in the table for stipulation 2D .1100 so that they reflect the averaging period of each corresponding pollutant’s TPER limit; no equipment was added or removed.

Description: These permits authorize construction of Trains 1-4 at the Port Arthur LNG Terminal and supersede the plant's expired permits to build Trains 1 and 2 (Permit Nos. 131769, PSDTX1456, and GHGPSDTX134), which were issued in February 2016. On Nov. 14, 2023, the U.S. Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Texas regulators failed to follow the Clean Air Act in issuing these permits. The panel of federal judges, based in New Orleans, wrote that they struck down the permits because the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality "declined to impose certain emissions limits on a new natural gas facility that it had recently imposed on another such facility. ... It therefore acted arbitrarily and capriciously under Texas law." The decision came in response to an appeal by the Port Arthur Community Action Network, represented by the Environmental Integrity Project and Lone Star Legal Aid.

Description: These permits authorize construction of the CCI Corpus Christi Condensate Splitter Facility. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has already granted two extensions to begin construction on the Condensate Splitter, first on November 7, 2016 and again on October 4, 2019. The second extension expired on December 19, 2019. On April 26, 2024, in response to a letter submitted by EIP regarding the permits' validity, the TCEQ confirmed that construction had not begun by the required deadline and that the permit holder "will be requesting to void the permit at a later date."

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the PTTGCA Petrochemical Complex, consisting of a new ethane cracker, two polyethylene units, and supporting infrastructure. The Ohio Department of Environmental Protection has already issued two extensions to begin construction on the Complex, on June 18, 2020 and February 23, 2021. The deadline to begin construction on the plant expired February 24, 2022.

Description: Permits authorizing initial construction of the Rio Grande LNG Terminal, which were extended on May 27, 2020 and set to expire on December 19, 2021. However, on November 13, 2020 NextDecade amended their Clean Air Act pre-construction permits to remove LNG Train 6 from design considerations, while keeping overall throughput and production volumes the same. That permitting action extended the deadline to begin construction to May 13, 2022. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality issued another extension on March 11, 2022, extending the deadline to begin construction until November 13, 2023.

M1 is a minor mod that would: 1) re-route various vents either to the Ethylene Unit flares or the Steam Unit boilers; 2) add a wax product loading; 3) add a column condenser which will be controlled by either to the Ethylene Unit flares or the Steam Unit boilers; and 4) add a distillation column, a storage drum, a vaporizer, and two heat exchangers which are all controlled by the Ethylene Unit flares.

Documents_OLD: {'name': None, 'file_name': '2017.3.15_Sendero Carlsbad Plant_7220 Statement of Basis.pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/d8/01/d8016a0607bd440b9a15f283097d6730.1639674661.pdf'}
ResearchNotes:
Process description (from SOB, pg. 3):
A mixture of natural gas, condensate, and produced water enters the Facility through a slug catcher where the gas is separated from the liquid phase. The separated gas is sent to an inlet scrubber prior to entering a molecular sieve dehydration unit where
the remaining moisture and heavier hydrocarbons are removed. Dry gas from the mole sieve then enters the cryogenic plant which is powered by electric compressor units. Natural gas liquids exit the cryogenic plant and are sent to residue compression
prior to being removed from the Facility via pipeline. The separated liquids are routed to a bag filter prior to being sent to a three phase sepeartor where the remaining liquids are removed from the stream and sent to the inlet scrubber. The liquids are sent to a NGL stripper where remaining NGLs are routed to overhead compression prior to being sent to the molecular siever dehydration unit. The separated condensate is sent to the condensate stabilizer. Remaining NGLs are separated from the condensate and stored in three 30,000 gallon pressurized storage tanks prior to being removed off site via tanker truck. The stabilized condensate is stored in six 1,000 barrel (bbl) atmospheric storage tanks prior to being removed off site via tanker truck. Produced water is stored in one 400 bbl atmospheric storage tank. Skid drains and spent compressor oil is routed to one 210 bbl atmospheric storage tank. Atmospheric storage and loading of condensate is controlled via enclosed combustor. Process heat is provided by a 34 MMBTU/hr hot oil heater. An emergency flare is onsite to control emissions during periods of malfunction.

Carbon Monoxide
9.8
Allowable
Nitrogen Dioxide
11.5
Allowable
Sulfur Dioxide

Allowable

Mod to PA-04-00740A issued 12/30/2016. PA-04-00740B and PA-04-00740C (issued 2/18/2021) -- AS 5/3/23 - removed from permit description; plant keeps getting extensions to construction permits because they will only apply for a TV after DEP conducts an inspection, after the shake down period

The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection has granted three extensions to construct the Shell Appalachia Ethylene Cracker, first on June 18, 2019, a second on October 23, 2021, a third on April 28, 2022, and the latest on September 13th, 2022. The latest extension expires on April 28th, 2023.
----
Emissions seen here are facility-wide post-mod PTE (incl. increase from Plan Approval PA-04-00740A) after issuance of Plan Approvals PA-04-00740B and PA-04-00740C. 88Taken from PA Bulletin (10/3/2020) page 59 of pdf. B and C permits quthorizes "as built" changes in design. 04-00740C authorizes numerous equipment additions and downsized/removed equipment (see PA Bulletin in S Drive, pg. 57-9). Decrease in MOx, CO, VOCs, increase 55,352 CO2e and all other criteria. 04-00740B authorizes period of temporary operation due to the installation of SF6 insulated high voltage equipment; PTE = 854, no criteria emissions increases. Permit was modified on 12/30/2016 to incorporated emission reduction credits secured by Shell; PTE unaffected. --

This permit authorizes construction of the Shintech Plaquemine Ethylene Plant (PEP-1). It was modified on June 20, 2016 (PSD-LA-788 (M-1)) to incorporate as-built design changes that were made during construction of the facility, and again on February 28, 2018 (PSD-LA-788 (M-2)) to update emissions limits for select sources without any physical modifications to the plant.
-------------
PSD-LA-788 (issued 12/4/2014), PSD-LA-788 (M1) (issued 6/20/2016), PSD-LA-788 (M2) (issued 2/28/2018), PSD-LA-788 (M3) (issued 12/12/2019), PSD-LA-788 (M4)(application for modification submitted 5/7/2021)

Description: Permit authorizing construction of a second PVC Unit (PVC-2) at Plaquemine Plant 3 (SPP-3) as part of Shintech's SPP-3 Expansion Project.
Documents: [{'id': 'dbbnhuh70d1cnbhtileqsrs0ds', 'name': '2021.1.19_Shintech SPP3 Expansion_Final Permit No. PSD-LA-817(M1).pdf', 'mediaType': 'application/pdf', 'enablePublicUrl': True, 'signedUrlTimeout': 60, 'uploadUrlTimeout': 86400, 'size': 26771973, 'version': 1, 'url': 'https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/bdrshnf9611hrbv9rr45mag0ok'}]
Documents_OLD: {'name': None, 'file_name': '2021.1.19_Shintech SPP3 Expansion_Final Permit No. PSD-LA-817(M1).pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/cd/7c/cd7ce448bc474a14a0d966ce43bf6738.1636502001.pdf'}
ResearchNotes:
PSD-LA-709(M3) is for the PVC-1 expansion project at Plant 1.
PSD-LA-817 is for the vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) facility, Plant 3, and the PVC-2 expansion project at Plant 3.
Purified VCM from SPP-3 is sent to SPP-1 or polymerized to form PVC. The initial Shintech Plaquemine Plant 3 (SPP-3) project submitted to the agency in 2017 included the expansion of the existing PVC unit (PVC-1) in SPP-1 and the addition of the units Chlor-Alkali 3 (C/A-3), Vinyl Chloride Monomer 3 (VCM-3)...expansion of Shintech's PVC and VCM production, which are currently under construction.

With PSD-LA-817(M1) application, Shintech is now proposing to modify the SPP-3 permit in order to further expand the complex's PVC production capacity with the addition of PVC-3. Shintech has additionally revised the emissions associated with the facility's scrubbers at SPP-1 as part of this expansion project.

**This modification would be considered as part of the same project as the initial SPP-3 expansion project .** Emissions seen here are PSD-LA-817(M1) post-mod increases, taken from M1 final permit, page 4. Emissions increases from 817M1 = PSD-LA-709(M-4), which (as of 2/15) is  undergoing public comment (although both permits authorize the same project(s) and 817M1 has already been issued...)

Description: Installation of a new cooling tower for the demethanizer (installed under Plan Approval No. 23-0119A) to accommodate the refrigeration of propane following fractionation.
ResearchNotes: Aggregated Projects, including: installation of a deethanizer unit (23-0119A); boilers and storage tanks (23-0119B); a cooling tower (23-0119C); storage tanks (23-0119F); cryogenic storage tanks, depropanizers and a debutanizer (23-0119E).

Description: Installation of a new 300,000-bbl refrigerated ethane storage tank, two new refrigerated propane storage tanks, a new 600,000-bbl refrigerated butane storage tank, a new dehydration system, a new 50,000-gal/min cooling tower, and the East Cold Flare. This modification also authorizes increased throughput to the demethanizer and the auxiliary boilers.
ResearchNotes:

C02 East Cold Flare (New Tanks Project)*

Description: Installation of a new 300,000-bbl refrigerated ethane storage tank; a new 500,000-bbl refrigerated propane storage tank; associated piping and components for the refrigerated product storage; the West Cold Flare; modifications to existing marine vessel loading docks and existing caverns.

Description: Installation of a new amine treatment system and a new dehydration system; modifications to the demethanizer and to increase steam use from three existing boilers.

Installation of a new system that would allow the facility to load natural gasoline feedstock and pentane onto tanker trucks; authorization of eight existing internal floating roof storage tanks, a fractionation tower, and a marine loading dock; and modifications to increase the use of steam and cooling water.

Description: “Project Phoenix” would allow the Marcus Hook Industrial Complex to receive, process, and store up to 140,000 barrels per day of ethane. It involves the installation of the following sources and equipment: Two new 600,000-bbl refrigerated ethane storage tanks; One new amine treatment system; One new dehydration train system; Two new refrigeration systems; Two new deethanizers; Two new wet surface air cooling (WSAC) systems; One new elevated, air-assisted Cold Flare; and Various piping connections and components. The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection has issued two construction extensions for this permit; the first extension pushed the deadline to begin construction to February 12, 2024, the second extension moved the deadline to August 12, 2025.

Description: This permitting action consolidates emissions sources located at the Nederland LPG Terminal - including LPG Trains 4 and 5, initially authorized on May 20, 2019 under Permit Registration No. 156074 - and separates them from emissions sources located at the neighboring Nederland Oil Terminal. A permit extension was issued on July 21, 2022, extending the deadline to begin construction on processing trains 4 and 5 to January 6, 2024.

ResearchNotes:
The trains at the Nederland LPG Terminal are currently authorized under PBR numbers 148950 and 156074.  This NSR permit will consolidate the trains under a single permit and update emission representations for all five trains and the flare. For the LPG terminal, Mariner South 1 (Train 1) was authorized in June 2013 and began operating in 2015. Mariner South 2 (Trains 2 and 3) was authorized in October 2017 and is expected to begin operations in mid to late November 2020. Trains 4, 5 - TBD.

https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=iwr.pgmdetail&addn_id=455518232020090&re_id=709367302020010&program_code=AIRNSR&lgcy_sys_cd=NSR&program=AIR%20NEW%20SOURCE%20PERMITS&IdType=PERMIT

Note that SPM&T authorized construction of the Mariner South 1 Terminal and the Mariner South 2 Terminal under similar PBRs in 2013 (PBR Registration 111204, voided in 2017) and 2017 (PBR Registration 148950).

ResearchNotes:
GHGPSDTX191, PSDTX1444M1, and 56508 (issued 7/13/2020, amended 8/13/2020, and 8/13/2021)

"The Nederland Terminal is comprised of a marine loading facility and two auxiliary tank farms. The main tank farm and loading facility is authorized by New Source Review (NSR) Permit Number (No.) 56508. The second tank farm known as South Tank Farm is less than 0.25 miles from the main facility and authorized by Permit No. 1980... SPM&T submitted an amendment and Greenhouse Voluntary update (VOLUPDATE) to fully consolidate Permit No. 1980/PSDTX1472M1/GHGPSDTX19 into Permit 56508, and increase gasoline throughput stored in four internal floating roof (IFR) storage tanks (emission point numbers [EPNs] 2100-2103), authorize storage tanks alternative control devices, and consolidate several Permits by Rule (PBRs)."  8/31/2021 amendment/voluntary update

ResearchNotes:
S-8943-1-0 (issued 11/21/2017) -- Emissions taken from Application Review (9/25/2017), page 28. NOx emissions are for NO2. Application for extension to the deadline of construction submitted 7/15/2019, asking for an extension until 11/21/2021. The Combined Cycle Gas Turbine/Heat Recovery Steam Generator is a New Source, Clean Emissions Unit with an independent purpose and SIC Code and is required to have an ATC and PTO, but not a PSD or Title V permit; whereas all Emission Units of the adjacent Ammonia Plant are Exempt and/or Low Emitting Units, Exempt from ATC or air permit requirements. Commencement of construction deadline = 11/21/2019; new deadline = 11/21/2021; Unknown if the extension has been granted, all application docs received by FOIA

Requested permit docs (extensions, renewals, modifications) from SJ Valley APCD on 1/7/2022. (GB 1/7/2022) --

Description:
Permit authorizing initial construction of Little Missouri Gas Plant 5. On January 12, 2021, Targa requested an extension to begin construction on Little Missouri Gas Plant 5, citing delays "due to recent market conditions." The North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality issued the extension on January 19th, giving the company until September 19, 2022 to begin construction on the project.



On September 13, 2022 the North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality conducted a site inspection and informed Targa that they would need to submit a new permit to construct application if construction had not begun by September 19, 2022 - see the Compliance Inspection Report page 7.

ResearchNotes:
Facility will be classified as a major source under PSD after LMGP Phase 5 construction is complete (source: Notice of Intent, Aug. 2019). Application for 18-month extension submitted 1/12/2021 (citing market conditions); issued 1/19/2021, extending the construction deadline until 9/19/2022. General permit app., Section C, page 93 of PDF states that construction is expected to begin "ASAP," construction duration not specified. Assumed construction will take more than 3 months and start-up in 2023.

No new permit apps available from CERIS ND; compliance inspection report from 9/22/2022 indicates that construction had not started nor had a new app been submitted by 9/13/2022. (GB 10/7/2022)https://ceris.deq.nd.gov/ext/nsite/map/results/detail/9170198996565466187/documents

ResearchNotes:
GHG language rescinded 9/16/2016 - NSR 101616, amended on 9/6/2016 to authorize construction of Train 6, on 10/2/2018 to to authorize construction of Trains 7-9, and on 2/5/2021 to authorize construction of Train 10.

https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=iwr.pgmdetail&addn_id=736434512012082&re_id=958514252001135&program_code=AIRNSR&lgcy_sys_cd=NSR&program=AIR%20NEW%20SOURCE%20PERMITS&IdType=PERMIT

https://www2.tceq.texas.gov/airperm/index.cfm?fuseaction=airpermits.project_report&proj_id=175653&addn_num_txt=101616

3/22/2013 = Initial NSR Permit 101616 was issued to Targa Midstream Services LLC to authorize construction of the Train 5 fractionation train at the Mont Belvieu Plant.

3/7/2016 = Permit 101616 was amended to reflect the as-built changes for the Train 5 project and add planned MSS emissions associated with Train 5. In addition, permit by rule (PBR) registration number 113495 will be incorporated by reference into this NSR permit. (pg. 28)

9/6/2016 = Amended to authorize construction of Train 6

10/3/2018 = Amended to authorize construction of Trains 7-9 (w/ GHG permit nos. GHGPSDTX26M1 and PSDTX696M2)

7/17/2020 = minor revision to revise the higher heating value (HHV) heat input rating for two heaters (EPN F-10 and F-11) associated with *Train 6* of the Mont Belvieu Plant. The new design capacity of the heaters will be 161.10 MMBtu/hr, with emissions based on the site-specific heating value of natural gas will be 1,038.5 Btu/scf.

2/5/2021 = Amended to authorize construction of Train 10

Description: This permit authorized construction  and operation of a new combined heat and power cogeneration system the Kenai Refinery. The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation issued a rescission letter for Minor Permit No. AQ0035MSS08 on November 5, 2021.

Description: The Jones Creek Terminal would consist of thirteen above-ground external floating roof storage tanks, with a maximum site-wide total storage capacity of approximately 9.2 million barrels of crude oil. The Terminal would receive crude oil through the proposed GulfLink pipeline and deliver it to tankers at the Deepwater Oil Port.

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the Brownsville LNG Terminal. On  September 28, 2021, Texas LNG Brownsville requested an extension to begin construction on the Texas LNG Terminal, citing "delays due to the global pandemic." The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality issued the extension on October 15th, giving the company until May 12, 2023 to begin construction on the project. A second extension was issued on June 8, 2023, pushing the deadline to begin construction back to November 12, 2024. A third extension was granted on July 22, 2024, which pushed the deadline to begin construction back to May 12, 2026.

ResearchNotes:
P0024292 (issued 7/13/2018) - initial construction
P0025440 (issued 6/21/2019) - modification to replace six engines and to add one emergency generator, three hot oil heaters, three IFR storage tanks, three 480-bbl storage tanks, one process flare
P0027359 (issued 6/17/2020) - modifying the heater ratings for HET001 and HET002 to reflect the actual ratings of the constructed heaters, increasing the horsepower of the emergency diesel generators (ENG008, ENG018) to allow up to a 470 hp engine, and adding process vents (VNT001) related to gas chromatograph analyzer vent emissions that were originally anticipated to be controlled by the plant process flare since routing to the flare has proved technically infeasible during facility construction. -- Emissions taken from permit P0025440, 2020 revision. Netting excludes fugitives; emissions seen here are new facility-wide totals post-mod (supersede previously issued permits). GHG emissions taken from permit application; criteria emissions taken from permit analysis. 2020 modification includes adjusting heater ratings and minor mods to as-built design parameters. Operating date reflects initial start-up following greenfield construction. --

Description: Initial construction permits authorizing installation of a new Methanol Unit at Ticona Polymers' Bishop Facility. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality issued an 18-month extension on May 19, 2017, which expired on November 12, 2018. Due to the company's inability to construct the Methanol Unit by the stated deadline, these permits were voided on January 18, 2022.

ResearchNotes:
104-0031-X007 and 104-0031-X008 (issued 8/28/2018), 104-0031-X005 (issued 4/22/2015), FERC Docket No. CP15-16 -- Emissions are from 104-0031-X007 and 104-0031-X008 (issued in 2018), which includes updated emissions "based on more representative data." Construction began during Phase 1; completed during Phase 2 (FEIS, Chapter 2). The proposed modifications to Compressor Station 95 are scheduled to occur in two phases. Phase l projects include the installation of one Solar Mars Turbine, addition of two bays gas cooling, and rewheeling of two existing Mars units. Phase 2 includes the addition of one Solar Mars Turbine, and rewheeling of three existing Mars units.

LM 12/8/2021:
phase 1 modifications: authorized by air permit 104-0031-X005. phase I construction began on 09/07/2016 and was placed into service on 05/01/2017.
phase 2 modifictions: authorized by air permit 104-0031-X007 and X008. phase 2 modifications were placed into service on 12/1/2019.
unsure where current emissions numbers came from....can't find in 104-0031-X007 and 104-0031-X008. need to split out permits --

ResearchNotes:
PSD-LA-805(M1) (issued 8/26/2019) = The purpose of this permit modification is to remove the emission sources associated with the batch concrete operations from PSD permit for the Calcasieu Pass LNG Project.

PSD-LA-805 (M-2) (issued 2/5/2020) = The purpose of this permit modification is to add one backup warm/cold flare, a second acid gas thermal oxidizer, two fire water pumps, and one 2000 gallon condensate tank.

PSD-LA-805 (M-3) (issued 2/2/2021) = Major permit amendment to authorize additional emissions sources, including two emergency generators and an emergency diesel tank; reconcile currently permitted emission sources based on updated vendor data and/or design revisions; and incorporate emissions from commissioning activities.

PSD-LA-805 (M-4) (issued 7/1/2021) = To reconcile emission rates from fire water pumps and the diesel storage tank.

Description: Permit authorizing initial construction of the Plaquemines LNG Terminal, which was modified on January 10, 2020 to remove emission sources associated with batch concrete operations. On July 10, 2020, Venture Global requested an extension to begin construction on the Plaquemines LNG Terminal, citing delays in obtaining "the necessary authorizations from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers." The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality issued the extension on July 30th, giving the company until April 25, 2022 to begin construction on the project.

ResearchNotes:
no construction deadline - in WV the permit remains active unless WV DEP pulls it -- last day to comment = 5/7/2021. Final permit to be issued 6/22/2021. Anticipated start-up date = 3/15/2023 (page 22 of permit app); construction to commence 3/15/2021 (page 29 of permit app), "The start-up of the first methanol unit and power plant should occur approximately 24 months after the commencement of construction. This will be followed by the second methanol unit starting up approximately 27 months after the commencement of construction and the third methanol unit approximately 30 months after the commencement of construction." To produce the methanol, the facility would use a maximum of approximately 36 mmft3/day of pipeline natural gas
(based on a heat input requirement of 1,500 mmBtu/hr and a nominal natural gas heat content of 1,000 Btu/scf).No GHGs in permit app, true minor. Application submitted 11/23/2020, updated 3/15/2021 --

ResearchNotes: G35-D139A (issued 2/7/2019), G35-D139 (issued 8/22/2018) -- Emissions are the sum of G35-D139 and G35-D139A. G35-D139A authorized: the addition of a 2 10-barrel produced water tank connected only to the separator dumps of the lean gas compressors (SO l -S04.) This tank will not be controlled by the facility flare. - The Installation of a SO-barrel waste oil tank for the lean compressors - The installation of a second emergency generator for additional back-up power - Reboiler S-17 was originally permitted as a 2.25 MMBTU/hr, that unit has been reduced to a I .5 MMBTU/hr reboiler. Dehydrators (S-18-19) maximum throughput has been increased to 115 MMSCFD - Dehydrator (S-12) has increased maximum throughput to 177 MMSCFD and operates on gas driven pumps - Dehydrator (S-I 3) has been removed --

Description: This significant permit modification authorizes the addition of selective catalytic reduction at two stabilization heaters and two cryogenic heaters, as well as the installation of four emergency generators, and numerous updates to equipment specifications and emissions calculations.

ResearchNotes:
7877M1 (second 30-day comment began 2/23/2021)

Proposed modifications:
1) Add selective catalytic reduction to two (2) stabilization heaters and two (2) cryo heaters
2) Remove two stabilization heaters
3) Reduce size/capacity of four (4) future internal floating roof tanks from 250,000 bbl to 100,000 bbl
4) Add truck loading of slop oil
5) Increase stabilizer overhead and cryogenic blowdown startup, shutdown, and maintenance (SSM) emissions
6) Update speciation profiles for several sources
7) Update fugitive counts apply NMED-approved emissions reductions
8) Update tank throughputs
9) Add four (4) emergency generators
10) Update equipment nomenclature and unit numbers
11) Add/show electric compressors that have NSPS OOOOa applicability
12) Consolidate MSS floating roof tank landings under general SSM related VOC emissions at a rate of 10 tons per year per NMAQB guidance
13) 10 TPY malfunction emissions are being added to the permit
14) Increase flare purge gas flow rates

Description: These permits authorized construction of the Port Arthur Ethane Cracker. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) issued two 18-month extensions - first on August 16, 2021 and again on March 13, 2023 - giving Motiva until August 6, 2024 to start building the new unit. Because construction did not begin by the required deadline, TCEQ voided the permits on September 9, 2024, at the company's request. If Motiva wants to move forward with the project, it will have to apply for a new air  construction permit.

Issued with nonattainment permit no. N166M3. Chevron Phillips submitted an amendment application to construct a new 1-Hexene unit at their Sweeny site. The proposed facilities include a flare, a cooling tower, a thermal oxidizer, a vapor combustion unit, storage tanks, truck and railcar loading, drum loading, and piping component fugitives. The project emission increases of VOC and NOx are above the major modification thresholds, so Nonattainment New Source Review is required. The permit requires that NNSR offsets for VOC and NOx be obtained prior to construction, at a ratio of 1.20 to 1. The MSS activities for these proposed facilities will be authorized in this permit by this permit action.

Description: Authorizes modifications to the refinery's sulfur recovery complex and amine units so the refinery can handle crude with higher sulfur content.

ResearchNotes:
Significant permit revision to Permit No. 151-39409-00067 (application submitted 4/1/2018) -- "The facility will be adding 24 new Plastic Conversion Units (PCUs) and associated Feedstock Preparation (FP) area and Fuel Processing equipment, storage tanks and loading rack to the east and west of the existing Ashley site. When that
construction is completed, Brightmark will be adding two (2) new PCUs to the existing Ashley site for a total of eight (8) while removing the FP bottleneck. The eight PCU area will be using only natural gas for fuel. The process (noncondensible) gas from all 32 units will be used as a fuel source at the 24 unit area and will then be controlled by two (2) Selective Catalvtic Reduction (SCR) units." (app, pg 22) --

ResearchNotes: Construction and operation of a 580 tons-methanol/day natural gas-to-methanol plant in a portion of the Dow Chemical Company (Dow) facility located in Institute, Kanawha County, WV. As originally permitted, the facility was to receive 15.35 mmft3 /day of pipeline natural gas and convert it into 580 tons-methanol/day.

Description: Permit modification to include an addition of a 96.76 mmBtu/hr Auxiliary Boiler, two 324 horsepower emergency generators, an induced-draft Cooling Tower, and facilities that would allow US Methanol to transport methanol by truck and railcar. These modifications increased methanol production capacity from 580 to 661 tons per day.

ResearchNotes:
TCEQ Permit No. 100091 issued 11/14/2012; extended 4/15/2014 (until 11/12/2016), revised 11/17/2014, amended 4/5/2016, revised 8/20/2021

PSDTX1286 and GHGPSDTX6 (issued 11/14/2012 amended 4/5/2016 and 4/20/2020) -- REVISION	8/20/2021 = to modifying the existing Special Condition (SC) No. 14 to allow the use of continuous monitoring for the conductivity of the cooling towers
(EPNs HT16.028A and HT16.028B). Additionally, footnote (5) on the MAERT is being added. (no change in emissions)

AMEND 4/05/2016 =  to "incorporate process information and emissions that were not available when the original permit was issued."

REVISION	11/17/2014 = to authorize "addition of ethane, Pressure Swing Adsorber off-gas, and a natural gas-like fuel to the list of allowable fuels in Special Condition No.7" (no emissions increases).

REVISION	4/15/2014 = extension until 11/12/2016

https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=iwr.pgmdetail&addn_id=313336592011354&re_id=592664812002142&program_code=AIRNSR&lgcy_sys_cd=NSR&program=AIR%20NEW%20SOURCE%20PERMITS&IdType=PERMIT

Permit expiration date taken from:
https://www2.tceq.texas.gov/airperm/index.cfm?fuseaction=airpermits.project_report&proj_id=328634&addn_num_txt=100091 -- 18 month extension to commence construction granted on 4/15/2014, authorizing extension until 11/12/2016. TCEQ Permit No. 100091 revised on 11/17/2014 to authorize "addition of ethane, Pressure Swing Adsorber off-gas, and a natural gas-like fuel to the list of allowable fuels in Special Condition No.7" (no emissions increases). TCEQ Permit No. 100091 amended 4/5/2016 to "incorporate process information and emissions that were not available when the original permit was issued." Criteria emissions seen here are from 4/5/2016 permit amendment, technical review (proposed allowable); GHGs from GHGPSDTX6, voluntary update (4/20/2020). **The DIB unit originally authorized with TCEQ Permit 100091 was never constructed.** Enterprise announced plans in 2017 to construct a new isobutane dehydrogenation (“iBDH”) unit at our Mont Belvieu complex that is expected to have the capability of producing 425,000 tons per year of isobutylene." (https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1061219/000106121917000008/form10k.htm). Frac VIII placed into service 11/2013.

Description: Permit modification authorizes the conversion of an external floating roof tank to an internal floating roof tank, an increase in hp for a fire water pump engine, and addition of crude oil lab equipment for on-site testing of crude oil.
Documents: [{'id': 'a83pf5uj014uv7upcu8tl8phro', 'name': '2019.09.04_Keyera Energy - Wildhorse Terminal Initial Construction_2016-1066-C (M-1) PSD Permit Memorandum.pdf', 'mediaType': 'application/pdf', 'enablePublicUrl': True, 'signedUrlTimeout': 60, 'uploadUrlTimeout': 86400, 'size': 69211364, 'version': 1, 'url': 'https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/ksc5pe4pb17hddfkr2u7lutbuk'}, {'id': '2gnuvnd0a93893cqoncto8dv9k', 'name': '2019.09.11_Keyera Energy - Wildhorse Terminal Initial Construction_Final Permit 2016-1066-C (M-1) PSD.pdf', 'mediaType': 'application/pdf', 'enablePublicUrl': True, 'signedUrlTimeout': 60, 'uploadUrlTimeout': 86400, 'size': 24752251, 'version': 1, 'url': 'https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/m79slm61u966v3bkbc9njoplig'}]

ResearchNotes:
2016-1066-C PSD (issued 6/29/2017), 2016-1066-C (M-1) PSD (issued 9/11/2019 to Keyera Energy Inc.) -- One of the tanks authorized by Permit No. 2016-1066-C (PSD) was a 20,000-bbl external floating roof (EFR) tank (T-201). KEI is requesting to convert this proposed tank from an EFR to an internal floating roof (IFR) tank. This proposed change is considered a significant modification because it involves a change in a permit condition that is required to be based on a case-by-case determination; therefore, the application will be processed as a Tier II.

In addition, the following updates will be made:
-Change one of the 176-hp emergency-use diesel fire water pump engines to a 700-hp emergency-use diesel fire water pump engine.
-Add crude oil lab equipment (one 500 gallon solvent container and one 1,000 gallon sump tank) to the facility to allow for testing of crude oil on-site. -- Submitted FOIA for any permit applications and permit memorandums issued after the M-1 permit mod (9/11/2019), plus any construction completion notifications and their current TV operating permit on 9/17/2021 and received a response on 9/17/2021. All produced docs are in the project folder.

Submitted another FOIA for current Title V operating permit, any pending air permit applications, and any post-9/11/2019 construction completion notifications on 12/17/2021 (GB).
