NSR 101616, amended on 9/6/2016 to authorize construction of Train 6, on 10/3/2018 to to authorize construction of Trains 7-9, and on 2/5/2021 to authorize construction of Train 10.

3/22/2013 = Initial NSR Permit 101616 was issued to Targa Midstream Services LLC to authorize construction of the Train 5 fractionation train at the Mont Belvieu Plant.

3/7/2016 = Permit 101616 was amended to reflect the as-built changes for the Train 5 project and add planned MSS emissions associated with Train 5. In addition, permit by rule (PBR) registration number 113495 will be incorporated by reference into this NSR permit. (pg. 28)

9/6/2016 = Amended to authorize construction of Train 6

10/3/2018 = Amended to authorize construction of Trains 7-9 (w/ GHG permit nos. GHGPSDTX26M1 and PSDTX696M2)

7/17/2020 = minor revision to revise the higher heating value (HHV) heat input rating for two heaters (EPN F-10 and F-11) associated with *Train 6* of the Mont Belvieu Plant. The new design capacity of the heaters will be 161.10 MMBtu/hr, with emissions based on the site-specific heating value of natural gas will be 1,038.5 Btu/scf.

2/5/2021 = Amended to authorize construction of Train 10

Description: These permits authorized construction of a tenth fractionation train at Targa's Mont Belvieu Complex. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality extended the construction deadline on July 27, 2022, giving the company until February 5, 2024 to start building the new unit.

3/22/2013 = Initial NSR Permit 101616 was issued to Targa Midstream Services LLC to authorize construction of the Train 5 fractionation train at the Mont Belvieu Plant.

3/7/2016 = Permit 101616 was amended to reflect the as-built changes for the Train 5 project and add planned MSS emissions associated with Train 5. In addition, permit by rule (PBR) registration number 113495 will be incorporated by reference into this NSR permit. (pg. 28)

9/6/2016 = Amended to authorize construction of Train 6

10/3/2018 = Amended to authorize construction of Trains 7-9 (w/ GHG permit nos. GHGPSDTX26M1 and PSDTX696M2)

7/17/2020 = minor revision to revise the higher heating value (HHV) heat input rating for two heaters (EPN F-10 and F-11) associated with *Train 6* of the Mont Belvieu Plant. The new design capacity of the heaters will be 161.10 MMBtu/hr, with emissions based on the site-specific heating value of natural gas will be 1,038.5 Btu/scf.

2/5/2021 = Amended to authorize construction of Train 10 --

Description: This significant permit modification authorizes design changes that modify the plant's capacity and result in emissions reductions, and extends the deadline to begin construction on the Midwest Fertilizer Plant—for the fourth time. On June 18, 2019 the facility's Title V Operating Permit was also renewed (Permit No. 129-40329-00059).

ResearchNotes:
https://www.in.gov/apps/idem/caats/sourceDetail.xhtml?sourceId=129-00059 -- Midwest Fertilizer is unable to meet the September 23, 2021 commencement of construction deadline due to complications resulting from COVID-19 restrictions. As a result of being unable to meet the construction extension deadline, as permitted in Administrative Amendment No. 129-42647-00059, Midwest Fertilizer is required to obtain a new New Source Construction and Part 70 Operating Permit for its planned nitrogen fertilizer production facility. Midwest Fertilizer is taking this opportunity to revise the facility footprint and is providing updates to the planned facility.

Permit No. 129-33576-00059, was originally issued in June 2014 and has been modified twice (first on March 23, 2020 and again on June 3, 2019) and extended four times (on September 28, 2015, May 9, 2017, September 20, 2018, and March 17, 2020).

This permit would supersede Midwest Fertilizer's initial pre-construction permit, Permit No. 129-33576-00059, which was originally issued in June 2014 and has been modified twice (first on March 23, 2020 and again on June 3, 2019) and extended four times (on September 28, 2015, May 9, 2017, September 20, 2018, and March 17, 2020).

No final permit as of 2/9/2022. GB --

Description: This application requests a third extension to begin construction on the TopChem Ammonia Plant, stating that, as a result of "the COVID-19 pandemic, investment decisions have been slowed down worldwide ... [and] that the BACT presented in the current permit is still accurate." If approved, the deadline to start building the new facility would have been pushed back to December 22, 2022, but on November 8, 2022, TopChem withdrew its application and rescinded its construction and operating permits.

Description: According to the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, this is a first time Part 70 permit with a minor amendment rolled in. This permit action will add a third natural gas-fired turbine and one additional process heater to the existing Faribault Compressor Station. With the addition of the new emission units, the facility's potential to emit for NOx and CO will exceed Part 70 permit thresholds and is the reason for a first time Part 70 permit.

Description: This is the third 18-month extension requested by the Port of Lake Charles/Lake Charles Harbor & Terminal District to construct a Methanol & Sulfuric Acid Bulk Terminal. Since the Port's request was submitted after the August 11, 2021 construction deadline, it was denied by the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality on June 22, 2022. The permit was officially rescinded on March 13, 2023.

Description: Major permit modification to construct four liquefaction trains (Trains 1-4) at the existing Sabine Pass LNG import terminal. This permit was modified on March 22, 2013 to incorporate revised modelling data and update emissions calculations.

Documents_OLD: {'name': None, 'file_name': '2011.12.6 Sabine Pass LNG PSD-LA-703 (M3) Final Permit.pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/e8/07/e8077ec26cd8443998caccb4f3816558.1638199851.pdf'}, {'name': None, 'file_name': '2013.3.22 Sabine Pass LNG PSD-LA-703 (M4) Final Permit.pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/7d/2f/7d2f6ae36e4947608d5cf20d9f69a467.1638200105.pdf'}
ResearchNotes: M4 permit modification to incorporate the following changes to the proposed liquefaction trains: I) Add four thermal oxidizers for controlling the acid gas vents; 2) Replace two proposed natural gas-fired emergency generators with four diesel-fired units; 3) Install a heavies removal unit which. consists of two internal floating roof (IFR) tanks and truck loading operations; 4) Add four insignificant diesel storage tanks; 5) Change the control options of two proposed gas-fired generator turbines from wet low standard annular combustion (SAC) or water injection to dry low emission (OLE) operation; 6) Increase· emissions from the proposed liquefaction trains; 7) Revise stack parameters and equipment coordinates of various pieces of equipment; and 8) Revise/update the modeling report based on the updated stack parameters, equipment coordinates, and monitoring data.

Description: Permit modification to consolidate two previous permits (Nos. 7777 and 19778) and to increase plant production.
ResearchNotes:
GHGPSDTX155 (issued 1/5/2017), PSDTX1326 (issued 1/10/2014), 19778 (amended 1/10/2014 and 10/06/2014) -- https://www15.tceq.texas.gov/crpub/index.cfm?fuseaction=iwr.pgmdetail&addn_id=20848192002163&re_id=430060532002089&program_code=AIRNSR&lgcy_sys_cd=NSR&program=AIR%20NEW%20SOURCE%20PERMITS&IdType=PERMIT

At that time, Permit No. 7777 was voided. Subsequently, Agrium obtained on 10/06/2014 an amendment to Permit No. 19778, to update the original application and to represent the project as built. After starting construction, Agrium determined that it required maintaining in effect the pre-2014 permit conditions and emission rates of the two previous permits, until modification of both plants is completed. The amended permits which Agrium requested and which were issued in 2014 did not contain pre-project and post-project emission rates that would allow for the modifications authorized in the 2014 amendments to occur. As a result, the as built permit amendment of 10/06/2014 restricted Agrium to emission rates and operational specifications which were not what Agrium required. The amended permit will create three transition stages, corresponding to advancing stages in construction of the Urea Manufacturing Plant and Ammonia Manufacturing Plant modifications. Special conditions and emission rates in effect will change with each transition stage.

**Upon completion of construction, expected to be in 2018, the permit will revert to the requirements of the permit issued on 10/06/2014.** --

Description: Synthetic minor permit authorizing initial construction of the Davis Refinery. Because Meridian failed to begin constructing the facility by the December 2019 deadline set out in its initial construction permit, the company requested an extension from the North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality (ND DEQ) on December 4, 2019, stating that ongoing litigation had caused delays in the financing and construction of the Davis Refinery and that construction would be completed in early 2023. ND DEQ granted the extension and postponed the deadline to commence construction on the Davis Refinery until September 12, 2021. On August 27, 2021, Meridian notified ND DEQ that its commitments under an "Engineering, Procurement, and Construction" (EPC) contract, which it entered into on June 12, 2021, qualified as commencing construction under the federal Clean Air Act. ND DEQ agreed with the company's assertions in a response dated June 9, 2021. ND DEQ concluded that Meridian had satisfied the terms of its air quality permit because it commenced construction before the September 12, 2021 deadline by entering into the EPC contract.

Description: This permit amendment incorporates Standard Permit Registration No. 136382, which authorized construction of Ramsey Plants II and III, by consolidation, and authorizes construction of standby generators and heaters to increase reliability at the plant. This permit also functions as an as-built amendment to Permit No. 117323 (issued 7/10/2015), which authorized construction of Ramsey Plants IV-VI.

ResearchNotes:
TCEQ Permit No. 117323 (issued 7/10/2015, amended 2/5/2016, 6/8/2016, and 3/22/2019) - pending revision (Project No. 334715, application submitted 10/26/2021, no permit documents online - AS 10/27/2021) -- TCEQ Permit No. 117323 (amended 2/5/2016) to remove 5 compressor engines (EPN: COMP-20 through COMP-24) that were originally permitted for the Ramsey V section of the plant, and to install electric engines instead

TCEQ Permit No. 117323 (amended 6/8/2016) = to update plant design. DBM decided to redesign the plans for equipment and layout of the plant before construction began. This amendment is for the plant as it will be constructed now. The former plant design included 15 natural gas-fired compressor engines, 5 heaters, 2 amine plants with 2 Regenerative Thermal Oxidizers (RTO), 1 flare, 3 blowdown points, and 3 fugitive sources. The redesign calls for 10 natural gas-fired compressor engines (the other 5 will be electric), 8 heaters, 1 amine plant with 1 RTO, 2 flares, 1 emergency generator, 5 blowdown points, 1 fugitive source, and 3 Maintenance, Startup, and Shutdown (MSS) emission points.

TCEQ Permit No. 117323 (revised 2/06/2018) to revise Special Condition No. 8.E. to fulfill Special Condition No. 26 - no change in emissions

Description: Application for a retroactive GHG permit and to amend Permit Nos. 122362 and PSDTX1430M1, which authorized construction of the Enbridge Ingleside Energy Center. These permits would incorporate as-built design changes and numerous revisions to emissions factors and calculations, increase annual storage tank throughputs and marine loading rates, authorize additional crude and condensate loading operations, and incorporate Permit Registration Nos. 159913 and 162551, by consolidation.

Description: This permit modification authorizes several updates, including: modifying the facility's boiler to run on purchased, pipeline natural gas (not fuel gas generated by the Renewable Diesel Project, as initially planned); installing a new naphtha tank, a cooling tower, and two emergency diesel engines; and numerous updates to emissions factors, calculations, and equipment representations.

ResearchNotes: Modify the Cheyenne Renewable Diesel Company facility by updating the 60 MMBtu/hr boiler (BOL001) to run only on purchased natural gas, updating the West Hydrogen Plant furnace (HET003) firing rate, updating the East Hydrogen Plant furnace (HET004) CO emission factor, updating the storage material for storage tanks (TNK002, TNK008), installing one (1) 445,410 gallon naphtha tank (TNK012), installing one (1) cooling tower (CTW002), removing the 650 hp Detroit 8v92 emergency pumping unit engine (ENG004), installing two (2) 542 hp emergency diesel engines (ENG014, ENG015), updating the thermal oxidizer (FLR002) emissions, and installing wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) slop loading (LUD003).

Description: Air Quality Plan Approval authorizing construction of a de-ethanizer, depropanizer, hot oil heater, regenerative heater, and rail load-out vapor recovery system at the Houston Gas Plant. This permit was modified on June 19, 2015 to authorize construction of the Houston 4 Gas Plant.
Documents: [{'id': 'li9c4nqogd45vbcs5b5g6oj9l8', 'name': '2012.10.4_MarkWest Houston Plant_Plan Approval 63-00936F.pdf', 'mediaType': 'application/pdf', 'enablePublicUrl': True, 'signedUrlTimeout': 60, 'uploadUrlTimeout': 86400, 'size': 6118177, 'version': 1, 'url': 'https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/sa28tg50t93e18b95cqbc8ir0k'}, {'id': 'dt7ei9f5t53ub0e0tfk30id41o', 'name': '2015.6.19_MarkWest Houston Plant_PA DEP Memo_Modification 63-00936F.pdf', 'mediaType': 'application/pdf', 'enablePublicUrl': True, 'signedUrlTimeout': 60, 'uploadUrlTimeout': 86400, 'size': 4340425, 'version': 1, 'url': 'https://us-east-1.storage.xata.sh/gdnq5u1nq51l3b196i1h4er78s'}]
Documents_OLD: {'name': None, 'file_name': '2012.10.4_MarkWest Houston Plant_Plan Approval 63-00936F.pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/5f/8e/5f8e118562f841b9949688ec0811d0b7.1636331148.pdf'}, {'name': None, 'file_name': '2015.6.19_MarkWest Houston Plant_PA DEP Memo_Modification 63-00936F.pdf', 'url': 'https://api.oilandgaswatch.org/d/f2/43/f243a5ea4a134359b86493c6aa85a655.1636331834.pdf'}
ResearchNotes:
63-00936F (issued 10/4/2012, modified 9/5/2013 and 6/19/2015); 63-00936I (application submitted 4/27/2021)

Emissions taken from 7/31/2012 email/calcs, pg 9 Table 6-1 (in S drive). Permit was modified in 2015 and facility-wide pte decreased by ~15k CO2e, but increases from F not included in calculation tables. On October 4, 2012, plan approval No. 63-00936F was issued to MarkWest to allow the installation and temporary operation of a deethanizer, depropanizer, hot oil heater, regenerative heater, and railyard vapor recovery system, as well as an increase of truck and rail load-out throughputs. On July 8, 2013, this plan approval was modified to incorporate plan approval No.’s 63-00936A, B, C, D, and E. On June 19, 2015, PA-63-00936F was modified to incorporate the Houston 4 gas plant, remove the Houston 2 hot oil heater, and adopt the requirements of 40 CFR Part 60, Subpart OOOO for the entire facility. New expiration date = 11/28/2021

deadline to construct = Jun 17, 2020 but permit superseded - permit status changed to "final issued" (from "void")

The plant wasn't built as planned, and the company submitted an application to modify the permit (and remove train 2) in April 2020. Looks like that permit app is still pending. DCP now expects the plant to be operational in 2024... but in 2018-2019 planned to bring the first stage online in 2020.

Description: This permit application would renew the facility's current Title V operating permit, 0520-00492-V2, and would serve as a de facto extension to PSD permit no. PSD-LA-803 (M-1), which authorized construction of the Lake Charles Methanol Facility and expired on August 24, 2020. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality issued a draft permit and solicited public comments in early 2022; however, a final permit was never issued. Lake Charles Methanol changed its name and applied for a new permit to build a "low-carbon" methanol plant in October 2023.

Permit application seeks to increase NOx emission factors for deethanizer heaters, and increase heat input for deethanizer regen heaters; increase flare throughput and remove hourly flare emission limits; increase heat input for stabilization heater; and incorporate and revise consent decree language. Permit application includes updated emissions calculations.https://dep.wv.gov/daq/permitting/Pages/NSR-Permit-Applications.aspx

Description: Permit No. 129-36943-00059 revised the Best Available Control Technology (BACT) assessments included in the Midwest Fertilizer's initial pre-construction permit, and  extended the deadline to begin construction to September 23, 2018. Another 18-month extension was issued on September 20, 2018 (Permit 129-40477-00059), giving the company until March 23, 2020 to start building the facility.

ResearchNotes:
This significant permit modification authorized air quality modeling analysis and updated Best Available Control Technology (BACT) assessments for most of the air emission units. This permit action extended the required date for commencing construction to September 23, 2018. An 18-month extension was again granted on September 20, 2018 with the new date set at March 23, 2020. -- On March 23, 2017 (T-129-36943-00059) a revised permit was issued that was based on an updated air quality modeling analysis and updated Best Available
Control Technology (BACT) assessments for most of the air emission units. This permit action extended the required date for commencing construction to September 23, 2018. An 18-month extension was again granted on September 20, 2018 (T-129-40477-00059) with the new date set at March 23, 2020. --

Description: This permit reauthorizes construction and operation of the Pelican Compressor Station in Hackberry, Louisiana. The facility's initial operating permit was issued in 2008 and expired in 2013. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality re-issued the permit in 2015, but LA Storage "decided to allow the permit to expire on December 21, 2020."

Final issuance date is the same as application date bc WV's lack of response to the permit extension request served as an approval.

west virginia code 45-13-10.2 "The Secretary may suspend or revoke a permit or general permit registration if, after (6) months from the date of issuance, the holder of the permit cannot provide the Secretary, at the Secretary’s request, with written proof of a good faith effort that construction, modification, or relocation, if applicable, has commenced. Such proof shall be provided not later than thirty (30) days after the Secretary’s request. If construction or modification of a stationary source is discontinued for a period of eighteen (18) months or longer, the Secretary may suspend or revoke the permit or general permit registration." (pg 14)

https://dep.wv.gov/daq/planning/Documents/45-13.pdf

ResearchNotes:
This permit seems to apply to both the Flexibility Project and the Rebuild Project. It allows for installation of new trays in the #2 DUF Stripper Tower (affecting permit 16-RAB-184) and decreases heat input for and language/limits applied to the hot oil heater (affecting permit 19-RAB-057). (GB 1/26/2022)

No emissions increases as a result of the permitted changes. (GB 1/26/2022)

Description: This significant permit modification increases the plant's gas processing capacity from 85 to 360 million standard cubic feet per day. Additionally, the permit modification makes multiple changes to and additions of equipment, increases flare volumes, adds up to six oil storage tanks, adds up to eight condensate tanks, adds up to five hot oil heaters, adds one regeneration gas heater, adds up to four amine units, adds up to two thermal oxidizers, adds one amine flare, adds one process flare, and adds one tank flare.

ResearchNotes:
As of the date of issuance, this Order supersedes NWCAA OAC 289a, issued April 12, 2012. -- draft issued in March 2021 and posted for public comment in June 2021. There doesn't appear to be a final permit online. KB emailed Robyn Jones (robynj@nwcleanairwa.gov) for status update on 3/2/22.

received final OAC289b from Robyn Jones on 3/2/22. She said "I don’t know if BP has started construction on the new cells, as they aren’t required to notify us."

OAC did not have deadline to begin construction, so assumed an 18 month period from final issue date. -- Draft Order of Approval to Construct (OAC) 289b: https://nwcleanairwa.gov/?wpdmdl=7465
Notice of Construction 289b Technical Worksheet: https://nwcleanairwa.gov/?wpdmdl=7465

Description: This permit would authorize instillation of a fourth ethane chiller train; a new boil off gas system for a refrigerated ethane product storage tank; new components for the feedstock metering, feedstock heating, amine treatment, and demethanizer off gas systems; and new piping, components, and process vents.

Description: This permit authorizes construction of a pre-treatment unit (PTU) to allow the  facility to treat raw renewable materials like fats and oils, installation of wastewater storage tanks and load-out facilities necessitated by the PTU, and converting a Calumet Refinery fractionation feed heater for use in the Great Falls Montana Renewable Diesel plant. Additionally, this permit is adding kerosene and a sustainable aviation fuel as products.

Description:
This permit authorizes construction of the HOC reconfiguration project.

Environmental Integrity Project attorneys worked with community groups in Texas to object to the issuance of a draft permit on the grounds that Valero’s best available control technology (BACT) determination for nitrogen oxides was deficient. Administrative Law Judge’s from the Texas State Office of Administrative Hearings agreed with the objections and recommended that the permit application and draft permit be denied, but the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality disregarded this recommendation and ultimately issued the permit. TCEQ’s decision and the full permit can be found here.

Description: This permit will authorize a facility to capture CO2 directly from the air. The equipment to be installed includes air contactors, a calciner and dryer, pellet grinders, a CO2 compression, dehydration and purification system, storage tanks, and emergency generators as well as storage silos, bins and material handling systems.

Description: These flexible permits authorized construction of a new cracking furnace at the Baytown Olefins Plant. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality has already extended the deadline to begin construction twice, first on February 5, 2021 and again on June 16, 2022, giving the company until May 6, 2024 to start building the new unit.

ResearchNotes:
Issued a Class II Air Quality Operating Permit, Permit No. AP2869-3306 on July 1, 2013 - expires on 7/1/2018

for the construction and operation of a municipal solid waste ("MSW') to renewable fuels biorefinery to be located at 3600 Peru Drive in the Tahoe-Reno lndustrial Center near the community of McCarran, in Storey County,
Nevada.

The Air Permit currently will expire on July 1, 2018 and Sierra BioFuels has several revisions to the facility that must be incorporated into a renewed permit.

Description: Plan Approval application for Phase 1 of the Encina Point Township project, which would consist of a new plastics sorting facility. Description: This modification to the facility's construction and operating permits would increase hours of operation and operating rates for some equipment and update Best Available Control Technology (BACT) and emission rates. It would broadly authorize the "final design" of the project, since it has already been constructed and has already started operating. The initial permit application is available here and additional information submitted on September 8, 2023 is available here. Maps posted for the public hearing are available here. The draft permit and other documents posted for public review are available here.

Description: This permit amendment authorizes conversion of the technology utilized for chlorine production from diaphragm cell technology to membrane cell technology. Description: These permits would authorize modifications to the facility's Greater EDC Unit, Bottoms Plant, TE-2 Unit, and Incinerators Area as part of Project Sustainability. They would also authorize construction of two new Halogen Acid Furnaces and a new EDC production train. See the permit application here. On November 6, 2024, Westlake requested that permit review be placed on hold because it is "evaluating a scope change" for the project. Although the application will remain pending, the company asked the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality to suspend work until it can provide updated information.
